Chang-Yu Chang 張昌祐
Assistant Research Fellow
Email: changyuchang5@gmail.com
CV · GitHub · Google Scholar · BlueSky
Chang-Yu (he/him) began his fascination with biology as an undergraduate and later earned a master’s degree in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at National Taiwan University, where he studied beetle behavior. He then moved to the US for a PhD in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at Yale University, where he investigated microbial community assembly and developed quantitative approaches to predict and engineer the emergent properties of microbial consortia. As a postdoctoral fellow in the Department of Biology at the University of Pennsylvania, he turned his focus to the evolution of host–symbiont systems. After several years on the East Coast, he returned to Taiwan in 2025 to join the Biodiversity Research Center at Academia Sinica as an Assistant Research Fellow.

title: Laboratory for microbial symbiosis, ecology, and evolution
text:
Community diversity is often greater than what pairwise interactions would predict.
Our work has shown that higher-order interactions can generate emergent coexistence, allowing multispecies communities to persist even when pairs of species fail to coexist. Building on this principle, we aim to develop predictive frameworks for community assembly — asking when species combinations will converge on repeatable outcomes, and when history or chance dominates.
Chang et al 2024 Science.








Microbial communities can be treated as evolving units, subject to artificial selection.
In experimental evolution systems, we found that community function can be improved by selection until heritable variation is exhausted. Our research identified strategies — stabilizing communities and perturbing ecological states — that extend this improvement. These insights point toward a design framework for microbiome engineering, where communities can be optimized for desired traits.
Chang et al 2020 Evolution, Chang et al 2021 Nat Ecol Evol.








Facultative symbionts live dual lives: free-living and host-associated.
Using population genomics and laboratory assays, we study how these multitudes of life stages shape the genetic diversity and divergence in microbial symbionts Our work on host–symbiont systems explores how microbial symbionts adapt across hosts and environments.
Chang et al 2025 bioRxiv.

title: Laboratory for microbial symbiosis, ecology, and evolution
section: Theme I — Diversity at the level of host communities
text:
Theme I — Diversity at the level of host communities
Question: What drives the diversity in symbiosis at the level of host communities?
- Determinism (host selection): symbiont communities differ across co-occurring hosts.
- Contingency (spatial proximity): symbiont communities differ across sampling sites and natural gradients (urbanization, elevation).
Approaches:
- Field transect sampling
- Metagenomics
- De novo genome assembly
- Phylogenomics

title: Laboratory for microbial symbiosis, ecology, and evolution
section: Theme II — Diversity at the level of symbiont communities
text:
Theme II — Diversity at the level of symbiont communities
Question: What drives the diversity in symbiosis at the level of symbiont communities?
- Determinism (competition): symbiont communities are highly repeatable across host replicates.
- Contingency (neutrality): symbiont communities differ across replicate hosts.
Approaches:
- Symbiont community enrichment experiments
- Synthetic community construction
- Metagenomics
- Mathematical modeling

title: Laboratory for microbial symbiosis, ecology, and evolution
section: Theme III — Diversity at the level of symbiosis islands
text:
Theme III — Diversity at the level of symbiosis islands
Question: What drives the diversity in symbiosis at the level of mobile symbiosis islands?
- Determinism (selection at gene/genome level): gene sweeps or genome sweeps across symbiont communities.
- Contingency (horizontal gene transfer): fixation of symbiosis islands depends on idiosyncratic HGT events.
Approaches:
- Synthetic community experiments
- Molecular genetics
- Gene editing and tagging
- Computer vision assays

title: Laboratory for microbial symbiosis, ecology, and evolution
text:
We are a new group at the Biodiversity Research Center, Academia Sinica in Taipei, Taiwan. The lab officially launches in November 2025, and we welcome applications at all levels. Join Us!
Our research sits at the interface of ecology, evolution, and systems biology. We study host-associated microbial communities— complex systems layered by hosts, symbionts, and mobile genes—with the goal of uncovering the simple rules that govern them. By integrating fieldwork, laboratory experiments, and theoretical models, we ask when and how diversity across multiple levels of organization emerges, persists, or collapses.

title: Laboratory for microbial symbiosis, ecology, and evolution
text:
Research Themes
Our work aims to uncover the rules that govern how microbial communities form, persist, and evolve. We combine laboratory experiments, evolutionary theory, quantitative modeling, and genomics to link ecological processes with evolutionary outcomes across scales.

title: Laboratory for microbial symbiosis, ecology, and evolution
section: Theme III — Evolution of host–microbial systems
text:
Theme III — Evolution of host–microbial systems
Microbial symbionts live dual lives: free-living and host-associated.
Using population and quantitative genomics, we study how these transitions shape genetic diversity and divergence. Our work on host–symbiont systems explores how selection, historical contingency, and horizontal gene transfer interact to drive adaptation across hosts and environments. Ultimately, this research links ecological context to evolutionary change in facultative symbioses.
